ac:rich-text-body.p: The following sections describe recurring or generic structures and dependencies among any set of building blocks â€“ possibly even across different levels.
We call a dependency or structure generic if it appears more than once in the architecture.

An example is the structure of getting data out of a relational database via the model or application-layer up to the graphical views - which will quite often be implemented using the same structures and patterns throughout the application, regardless of the concrete data (class, domain-entity) involved.
Use building block models (class diagrams, package diagrams, component diagrams, etc.) and related descriptions in the same way as in the hierarchical decomposition.
Often it is practical to support understandability by adding specific runtime views to these recurring structures.
